Common reasons for inaccurate measurements.
1. The cuff is too tight or too loose. When measuring blood pressure, the cuff should be tightened appropriately. Too tight or too loose will have a greater effect on the blood pressure value (it is best to keep 2 fingers free between the cuff and the arm) The cuff is tied 2 to 3 cm above the elbow joint of the arm.
2. Incorrect position of the blood pressure measurement. When measuring blood pressure, the arm should be positioned correctly and the height of the sphygmomanometer, the cuff and the heart should be the same, otherwise the results will be affected.
3. Inadequate self-preparation: being in an emotionally unstable state when measuring blood pressure, or not resting after strenuous exercise, talking while taking blood pressure, etc. will usually result in a high measured blood pressure value; (no food, water or exercise for 30 minutes before the measurement and emotional stability)
Tip: If you are emotionally stable, the blood pressure measured will be more accurate, otherwise high mood swings will interfere with the measurement, no matter what blood pressure monitor is used.
4. Do not compress any blood vessels on your body during the measurement. (including but not limited to stretching your legs, improper measurement position, clenching your fists, bending over, sitting cross-legged or curled up on a sofa or low table) can cause local pressure. Please take measurements in the correct sitting position (please refer to the instructions).
5. Inaccurate measurements can also occur when the electronic blood pressure monitor is low on power (replace the batteries or use the USB cable).

When should I check my blood pressure?
A person's blood pressure varies throughout the day, so it is normal to get different readings at different times and on different days.
The best time to measure your blood pressure is within one hour of waking up in the morning, or before going to bed at night. If measuring in the morning, do so within an hour of waking up, after urinating and before breakfast (or before taking blood pressure medication if you are taking it). If measuring in the evening it is recommended to do so before going to bed. For other times of the day, it is best to measure when your body and mood are stable. It is also recommended that measurements are taken at the same time of day.
Factors such as caffeine, exercise, alcohol, stress levels and the time of day can all affect blood pressure. Try to take your blood pressure at the same time of day. Keep a record of all your blood pressure readings and the time of day. It can be helpful to repeat the blood pressure measurement again in 1-2 minutes and use the average of the 2 readings.

Frequently Asked Questions
Will the cuff fit my arm?
Cuff size is dependent upon the circumference of the arm (measured in the center of the bicep). The permissible range is printed on the cuff and our cuffs are a universal size, fitting 8.7 inches - 15.7 inches (22-40 cm) arms. Measure your arm to make sure the cuff will fit you.
How to understand that the device detected an arrhythmia?
If you see three heart symbols on the screen, it indicates that the device has found an arrhythmia, which is a disruption in your heartbeat. This might mean that you need to relax, calm down, and not speak during the measurement. If the symbol appears several times in a single week, we recommend going to a doctor.
Why is there a Micro USB plug on the device?
Blood Pressure Monitor comes with batteries included so that you can use it as soon as its delivered to you. You may also operate this monitor using an AC adapter. Use only the approved AC adapter to avoid damaging the unit. Do not use batteries and the AC adapter at the same time. AC adapter is not included.
Is it possible to disable the sound ?
You can turn this feature off if needed. To do this, watch the video or read the instructions. In the future, it can be easily turned on so that the device again starts voicing measurement results.
How do I measure my blood pressure to obtain accurate results?
Relax before measuring
Wait 30 minutes before measuring after drinking coffee, taking a bath, or any physical activity. Before turning on the device, sit straight up in a chair, put your feet flat on the ground, and relax.
Put on the cuff
Place the cuff on your left arm above your elbow so that the edge is about 1 inch (2-3 cm) above your elbow joint and the tubes are in the middle of your arm facing your body and hanging down.
Place your elbow and turn it on
Put your left palm up and place your elbow on a table or flat surface. Sit straight and relax, don't move or talk, and breathe regularly. Turn on the blood pressure monitor.
Get the result
The results will appear on the screen within a minute. You'll see your systolic pressure, diastolic pressure, and heart beats per minute. Please follow the measurement rules every time, it greatly affects the result.

Health science tips - common issues with blood pressure
Hypertension and hypotension are two cardiovascular conditions associated with blood pressure irregularities, and both may pose different health risks.
Dangers of Hypertension:
Increased Cardiovascular Risk: Hypertension places an increased load on the heart, raising the risk of cardiovascular diseases such as heart enlargement, coronary artery disease, and heart attacks.
Elevated Stroke Risk: Hypertension can lead to cerebrovascular diseases, increasing the risk of conditions like stroke due to its potential to damage blood vessels in the brain.
Kidney Issues: Hypertension may harm kidney function, leading to chronic kidney disease.
Vision Problems: Severe hypertension could cause retinal damage and even result in blindness.
Heart Failure: Prolonged high blood pressure might weaken the heart over time, leading to heart failure.
Dangers of Hypotension:
Fainting and Dizziness: Low blood pressure can result in oxygen deprivation, causing dizziness, fainting, or even unconsciousness.
Cardiac Problems: Low blood pressure may reduce the heart's blood supply, triggering heart attacks or arrhythmias.
Circulation Issues: Hypotension could decrease blood supply to organs, impairing their function.
Weakness and Fatigue: Low blood pressure may lead to feelings of fatigue, weakness, and lethargy.
Orthostatic Hypotension: Rapidly transitioning from lying down or sitting to standing could cause dizziness or fainting due to hypotension.
Whether dealing with hypertension or hypotension, both conditions require proper attention and management. If you suspect blood pressure irregularities, it's crucial to consult a doctor for accurate diagnosis and treatment recommendations.

Why do I need to monitor my blood pressure at home?
Checking your blood pressure at home is an important part of managing high blood pressure (hypertension).
The American Heart Association (AHA) and other organizations recommend that anyone with high blood pressure monitor his or her blood pressure at home. Home monitoring can help you keep tabs on your blood pressure in a familiar setting, make certain your medication is working, and alert you and your doctor to potential health complications.
Monitoring your blood pressure at home can:
Help with early diagnosis. Self-monitoring can help your doctor diagnose high blood pressure earlier than if you have only occasional blood pressure readings in a medical office.
Help track your treatment. The only way to know whether your lifestyle changes or medications are working is to check your blood pressure regularly. Monitoring blood pressure changes at home can help you and your doctor make decisions about your treatment, such as adjusting dosages or changing medications.
Encourage better control. Self-monitoring can give you a stronger sense of responsibility for your health. You may feel even more motivated to control your blood pressure with an improved diet, physical activity and proper medication use.
Cut your health care costs. Self-monitoring might decrease your number of visits to your doctor or clinic.
